events.name: Monthly Meeting
events.description:
Jason Purdy will be sharing his experience participating in the Google Cloud Developer Challenge.

2013 Google Cloud Developer Challenge
events.how_to_find_us: We'll be in The Vault, which is downstairs

events.name: Monthly Meeting
events.description:
Dart Flight School Preparation
This meeting is for those who are interested in volunteering at the Raleigh or Durham Flight Schools happening on February 8th.

We need volunteers to lead the tech talks, codelabs, or hackathons. Materials have already been created by others, but we need people who would like to go over the materials and present or manage the different sessions.

events.name: Dart Flight School - Raleigh
events.description:
Come celebrate the release of Dart 1.0 with us. 

Bring a laptop and an interest to learn something.

We'll have snacks, drinks, and swag until they run out.

Codelabs, Tech Talks, and a Hackathon are all possibilities for the time.

More details will come as time gets closer.

events.name: Dart Flight School - Durham
events.description:
Come celebrate the release of Dart 1.0 with us. 

Bring a laptop and an interest to learn something.

We'll have snacks, drinks, and swag until they run out.

Codelabs, Tech Talks, and a Hackathon are all possibilities for the time.

More details will come as time gets closer.

events.name: Monthly Meeting - DevArt
events.description: Details are still being worked out, but at the very least we'll be showcasing local Developer Art to highlight Google's DevArt project (https://devart.withgoogle.com). If you are, or know of someone who is, an artist who generates art with code please spread the word.
events.how_to_find_us: There is a parking garage just behind the building.

events.name: April Monthly Meeting - Google Cloud Platform
events.description:
Let's take a deeper look at the +Google Cloud Platform. We will watch an assortment of  #DevBytes and Cloud Platform Live videos. Additionally, we will look at the Developer Console, APIs, and how to get started with projects. We may even have a great discount code for people who attend to get some free Cloud Platform credit.

This month's meeting will be at +American Underground in downtown Raleigh.﻿

events.name: May Monthly Meeting
events.description: We'll be at American Underground on Main Street in Durham. There is not currently a topic for this meeting, so if you or someone you know has something they'd like to showcase (Android, Cloud Platform, Angular, Chrome Apps, etc.) we'll be open for talks. Otherwise we can talk about the latest Google Developer news, which includes the new Android Wear, Chrome enhancements, and some great developer videos just to mention a few things.

events.name: June Monthly Meeting - Golang
events.description: Join us in Raleigh at American Underground in June for a night dedicated to discussion of The Go Programming Language (http://golang.org/). We'll be joined by the Triangle Golang meetup group (http://www.meetup.com/Triangle-Golang-Meetup/) and we'll be discussing Gophercon (http://gophercon.com/), what people are working on with Go, and leave some time for spontaneous discussion of the language.

events.name: July Monthly Meeting - Google I/O Recap
events.description:
We're going to switch to the Raleigh American Underground. If this makes it so you can't join us I will try to post a Hangout On Air link for people to tune in remotely. We'll be discussing Google I/O and all the related news coming out of that.

Lightning talks of 5 to 10 minutes are always welcome too. Come show off the cool things you are doing with Google developer tools.
events.how_to_find_us: This is NOT the classroom on the American Tobacco Campus. The parking garage on Corcoran should be open and is conveniently right behind the building.

events.name: August Monthly Meeting - Polymer and Web Components
events.description:
Come join us at +American Underground in Durham on Main street this month for a look at +Polymer and +Web Components and the current state of the future of the web. +Kyle Buchanan and +Luke Dary will be walking through some code examples too, so bring a laptop.

There is a public parking garage right behind the building.
events.how_to_find_us: Note: this is NOT the American Tobacco Campus location

events.name: September Monthly Meeting - Hangout Lightning Talks and Google Developer Updates
events.description:
Hangout is linked off of the G+ Event: https://plus.google.com/events/cehdp2ss6n3aasb5pthn1n04rqg

Schools are starting up and Labor Day will be just behind us, so let's all stay comfy and meet virtually. We'll have informal time for people to share what they're working on either with lightning talks or just show and tell. We'll also take a look at recent announcements for Google Developer technologies and whatever else people want to discuss.

Things to discuss off-topic: GDG Triangle Women, DevFestNC 2014, and organizer help.

events.name: October Monthly Meeting - Chromecast and Android TV
events.description:
Join us at American Underground in Raleigh for an evening dedicated to looking at the Google Cast API for the Chromecast, and also the ADT-1 Developer Kit for Android TV. Presentations or demos focused on either technology are welcome.

Chromecast - https://developers.google.com/cast/
Android TV - https://developer.android.com/tv/index.html﻿

events.name: November Monthly Meeting - Google Cloud Platform Recap
events.description:
Sorry for the last-minute change, everyone. We'll be meeting in one week on November 11th. Topic will be the same though. In the meantime check out https://www.gcp-live.com/

We will look at the announcements and sessions from the Google Cloud Platform Live event. Additionally, we will look at other upcoming events like the Chrome Dev Summit. Lightning talks or other topics are welcome and encouraged.

Hangout event - https://plus.google.com/events/c9f7htdshtmb9doh2f95t9hcam4

events.name: December Monthly Meeting - Lunch at Trali
events.description:
This is our last meeting of the year. Let's do something a little different and get together over lunch and discuss the latest from the Chrome Dev Summit or whatever might be the topic du jour.

We'll meet around 11:30am at Trali Irish Pub and Restaurant near Brier Creek. If you are the first one there just ask for a large table we can try to accommodate a group with.

events.name: January Monthly Meeting - Gopher Gala Prep and Android Study Jam Info
events.description: Since the meeting is the week of the Gopher Gala and the Triangle Golang group is also having a Hack Night we'll use the time to do some planning for the Gala and also discuss the upcoming weekly Android Study Jam sessions that we're planning for February and March to help people work through the Udacity course on developing Android applications.

events.name: February Monthly Meeting - Hack Night
events.description:
Due to the state of the weather and roads we'll make this a Hangout-only meeting, but people are welcome to dial in if you'd like to share what you are working on, or want to take a look at something mentioned below.

https://plus.google.com/u/0/events/cuqoskvv15cm1jvupan3n33qivs
----------------------------------------------

Let's build something!

There are a lot of great things going on in all areas of the Google Developer landscape: I/O dates were announced, Android Study Jams ( http://developerstudyjams.com/ ), Google Cloud Platform Build-Off ( https://lp.google-mkto.com/NA-2015-GCP-Buildoff_Landing-Page.html ), and a lot of updates happening all around.

If you don't have your own project, you can work with someone else, hack on a GDG project, get your feet wet with a codelab, or just spend the time looking through code samples. We'll have something for everyone of any skill level.

events.name: March Monthly Meeting - Google Cast Hack Night
events.description:
Interest in the Cast API is high right now, so we are going to do a Cast hack night. This will be more coding than the previous look we took at the API, so bring a laptop, a Cast-enabled device if you've got one (Chromecast, Android TV, etc.), and an idea or two for something you want to cast.

I'm working on finding a venue that we won't run across the issues we've had with two-stage authentication getting in the way, so if you have or know of a place please let me know. There are some options to use a wireless router as a gateway, but I'd rather reduce the complexity if we can.

Useful Links
Getting Started - https://developers.google.com/cast/
Cast UX Guidelines - https://developers.google.com/cast/docs/ux_guidelines
Example Applications - https://github.com/googlecast/

events.name: April Monthly Meeting - Google Fiber and Gigabit Internet
events.description:
"What can you do with a gig?"

Join us at The Frontier for a discussion of the assortment of answers to this question. We'll have at least one speaker to help spur the discussion or answer questions and potentially more if they have availability.

Potential Topics to discuss include: network topology, impacts the extra speed has for development, innovations enabled by the potential for collaboration across gigabit-connected communities, and whatever else people might come up with.

Check out these links for some inspiration and potential communities to join:
http://1billionbits.com/
http://giglab.net/
https://us-ignite.org/apps/

events.name: May Monthly Meeting - Latest Google News and Lightning Talks
events.description:
Let's get together via Hangout and share the latest news from Google and whatever interesting projects we're working on, application demos, talks to practice, or anything that might be of interest.

If there isn't space in the Hangout we'll try to cycle people in and out and provide room for others. We may move to a Hangout on Air if a lot of people want to participate, but just check at the Google+ event for any updates: https://plus.google.com/u/0/events/c6srr4gmfpossr2vpiotm4ho0vs

events.name: June Monthly Meeting - Polymer 1.0
events.description:
We're breaking the third-Tuesday schedule this month, but the wait should be worth it. We will also attempt to have a livestream setup to record the session. Check the G+ event for livestream information: https://plus.google.com/events/co1vbt45l4irqcq6ekagrhkkieo

Polymer 1.0 is production-ready, so the only question to ask now is, "What will you build?"
There is already a great library of elements that Google has written for this version of Polymer, so we'll take a look at some of the existing components, examine the Polymer Starter Kit, and then dive in and create some of our own. If you haven't had a chance to take in Google I/O videos yet, give this session a view to get the "Polymer Keynote": https://youtu.be/fD2As5RmM8Q
events.how_to_find_us: When you turn into the 2800 area you'll see the Novelist sign. Park in front and meet in the conference room right by the front door.

events.name: July Monthly Meeting - TriangleJS: Real-Time Collaboration with Firebase
events.description:
This month we'll be joining up with TriangleJS to look at Firebase. Make sure to RSVP on the TriangleJS event as capacity is limited. Go here to RSVP: http://www.meetup.com/Triangle-JavaScript/events/223295288/

I will try to get a live stream of the presentation going also, so check our G+ page for more information on that. https://plus.google.com/+GDGTriangleNC/

"Adding real-time collaboration to applications can be tedious and laborious. But, backend-as-a-service provider Firebase makes it easy! Triangle JavaScript founder Lucas Myers will be joining us this month to dive into Firebase's real-time data API. We'll build a simple notes app and leverage Firebase and Angularfire to wire up 3-way databinding for real-time collaborative editing."

events.name: August Monthly Meeting - Rapid Paper Prototyping
events.description:
Date, time, and location may change, but the topic should not.

Come with an idea or an existing mobile app or mobile design challenge. We'll work toward three goals:

- Understanding why, when, and how to use paper-prototyping

- Getting experience applying material design to your app or site

- Recording a video to capture your new design or feature in motion

events.name: September Monthly Meeting - Chrome and DevTools
events.description: Jared Siirila will be sharing a deep dive into Chrome DevTools with us, and we'll also look at how to create Chrome Apps and what you can do with them. Bring a laptop.

events.name: October Monthly Meeting - Hangout
events.description:
Tonight we'll meet via Hangout and discuss what's new with Google, latest updates for the group, and give anyone that wants to present something time to do so from the comfort of wherever they might be.﻿

https://plus.google.com/u/0/events/c8g25a1oi2bjsoqs25ejojes928?authkey=CI_ko6aQ0bmObw

events.name: November Monthly Meeting - Hangout
events.description:
https://plus.google.com/events/cfejt6cr8a8heffr1cklrc4q390

We'll go over the latest news for Google Developer-related items, DevFestNC recap, group logistics, and upcoming meeting schedules.

events.name: December Monthly Meeting - Google Apps and Cloud Platform
events.description: To end the year we'll be looking at how to leverage Google Apps for Work to provide hosted solutions for everything from email to custom domains. Specifically, we will go through the process of publishing a Google App Engine app to serve a static homepage.

events.name: February Monthly Meeting - Lightning Talks and Latest News (Hangout)
events.description:
Have a talk you'd like to give, or some code you'd like to share? Come to our first meeting of 2016 from the comfort of your own home. We'll also be discussing some of the upcoming events we're planning for and inquire about topics you'd like to see discussed in future meetings.

If the Hangout is full we'll be monitoring event comments and the Q&A for additional discussion.﻿

events.name: Google Play Services Face Detection
events.description: Join us as Evan Halley from WillowTree, Inc runs us through the Play Services Face Detection API on Android. Part of the Mobile Vision APIs released in Play Services v7.8, Face Detection is an easy way to track faces and facial features.
events.how_to_find_us: Located in the American Tobacco Campus, WillowTree is in Bay 10 on the row of buildings on the west side of the campus. There is a doorbell to ring on the door facing the Ford dealership. Parking in the North and South ATC parking decks.

events.name: Google I/O Recap
events.description:
We'll meet at ReverbNation's office, who have graciously offered to provide food and drink as well. Space is limited, so please make sure you've noted your attendance and update it if your plans change so others are able to attend in person if possible.

Join us as we share some of the major announcements and experiences from I/O. This will be a moderately informal time with our own Patti Shin moderating the conversation (since she was in attendance in Mountain View last week).
events.how_to_find_us: Brightleaf Square parking lot may require parking pass

events.name: July Monthly Meeting - Google Updates and Share Your Projects
events.description: Join us via Hangout or live stream ( https://plus.google.com/events/ccrlabb3g1q50htob6otv0n3ul8 ) to hear the latest Google Developer technology updates and share any interesting code or projects you might be working on. Also, we'll share some news for upcoming events and plans for the GDG.

events.name: Women Techmakers Triangle Kick-off & Introduction
events.description:
GDG Triangle is excited to announce that will be holding our kick-off meeting for our sister group, Women Techmakers Triangle, this coming September!

Please come out for a great night of meeting other like-minded women in the Research Triangle Park area interested in Google technologies. 

Agenda:

• Brief introduction about Women Techmakers and WTM Triangle's vision for our meet-ups 

• Meet & Greet time

• Announcements and discussion on October meet-up topics

We would also like to whole-heartedly thank TEKSystems for graciously agreeing to host our first meeting at their new office in Raleigh. 

** Note: This event is open for all walks of life and not restricted to female attendees. Please do invite anyone who is interested! 

Stay updated with our group via twitter @WTM_Triangle.

WTM Triangle Google Plus Group

-- For recruiters --

Thank you so much for your interest!

Unfortunately, we are only allowing tech industry professionals to attend the meet-up.

Feel free to reach out to the hosts if you would like to learn more about us.

events.name: Made By Google Announcement at WillowTree
events.description:
WillowTree is inviting you all to their office in the American Tobacco Campus on October 4th at 12pm to watch the unveiling of Google's new hardware! Pixels! Daydreams! Chromecasts! Google Home! The possibilities are endless, but everything will be Made By Google. 

WillowTree will be providing food, drinks, conversation, and excitement – All you need to do is bring yourselves... and maybe some extra excitement.
events.how_to_find_us: Look for Bay 10 from the water side in ATC and Bay 9 from the Ford Dealership side on Julian Carr St.

events.name: Polymer Summit Recap
events.description:
Happy Holidays from GDG Triangle + Women Techmakers Triangle! 

Join us for a recap talk of the recent Polymer Summit with Luke Dary (Red Hat) and work through a code lab to create a Progressive Web App from scratch.

For more information about the event:

Polymer Summit 2016 London

Note: Food will be provided at the event!

Please don't hesitate to contact us for more information.

events.name: Firebase Developers Summit '16
events.description:
Hello! Join us for a viewing of the Firebase Dev Summit Keynote in Berlin this past November and to discuss the latest updates introduced.

Access to the summit videos can be found here: Firebase Summit '16

Food will be provided at the venue.

Looking forward to seeing you all there!

Merry Christmas + Happy New Year from 

GDG Triangle & Women Techmakers Triangle

events.name: Google IO Extended
events.description: Come join us for IO 2017 Extended! Please RSVP at https://www.universe.com/events/google-i-o-extended-chapel-hill-2017-tickets-MB8PH3

events.name: 3 Talks on Angular, AngularJS, Chrome, RxJS, Node & Atom
events.description:
Come hear about the latest in AngularJS and Angular technologies along with how to use Chrome, Atom, and Node to distribute code.

We are partnering with the Triangle JavaScript, Triangle Node meetup, Triangle Modern Web and TriAngular.jsfor this event. 

Distributed Code Sharing Using Node.js and Atom

Dan Seethaler - JavaScript Engineer at Convina

Brief - In this presentation I'll show you how we use Node.js, Atom, and Chrome to distribute our code base to our dev team. These tools allow us to do cool things like hot-reload our React apps, map backend errors directly to the files in our local editor, and send real-time code updates to other devs (think google docs). 

---

Practical RxJS and Angular JS 1.x

David Rogers - Senior Frontend Developer at Pendo.io

Brief - Do you struggle with applying RxJS to your projects at work, based solely on the canonical examples included in the documentation? Maybe, like Pendo, you haven't made the jump from Angular JS 1.x in your code base yet but would still like to make use of Observables and Subjects inside of plain ES6 services to ease the transition... or just solve some of the communication problems inherent in the framework. Would you just like some more concrete examples of how Observables can be used in real life development? If so, this talk is for you.

David Rogers will present two specific usage patterns we have employed using RxJS and Angular JS that allow us to dynamically update our UI based on continuous user input, along with some of the challenges and gotchas that we've encountered along the way. David will rely on working code samples in CodePen.ioextracted from the main Pendo application and visualizations from RxMarbles.com

---

Using Angular Material2

Tracy Lee - Google Developer Expert, Angular

Brief - We'll go over the various components of Angular Material, get familiar with the various components, walk through how to use them in your app, and a few tips and tricks to getting started.

STREET PARKING IS FREE OR PARK HERE 
http://www.godowntownraleigh.com/go/wake-county-parking-deck

events.name: PWAs & Mobile Apps w Vue.js & Framework7, Cross Platform Apps with React
events.description:
This is the quarterly Triangle Modern Web event! Please RSVP here. 

Partnered with Triangle Modern Web, Triangle JavaScript, TriAngular.js, RTP Angular, and more, join us at Pendo in Downtown Raleigh for this great event!

This October, we will be hosting a few special speakers from All Things Open!

Speaker : Simon Macdonald 

Topic : Building Mobile Apps with Vue.js and Framework7 

In this presentation we'll introduce Vue.js, setup a webpack build, extoll the virtues of its reactive data binding and composble interface all while building an Instagram like app. Using Framework 7 to provide the basic UI for Android and iOS for those of us, like myself, who are CSS challenged.Vue.js is a library for building interactive web interfaces. The goal of Vue.js is to provide the benefits of reactive data binding and composable view components with an API that is as simple as possible.Framework7 - is a free and open source mobile HTML framework to develop hybrid mobile apps or web apps with iOS & Android native look and feel. It is also an indispensable prototyping apps tool to show working app prototype as soon as possible in case you need to. 

Speaker: Tara Manicsic, Progress (KendoUI)

Topic: Progressive Web Apps For The Win! 

There’s a lot of talk about PWAs not being able to replace native mobile apps, and guess what. It’s true! That doesn’t mean we should dismiss them, it means we should take advantage of what they can do for our current web apps. Let's take our regular, already awesome, Angular app and 'progress' it to include pre-caching, home screen implementation & push notifications to make it faster and more engaging!

Speaker: Doug Miller,  Citrix Systems, Inc

Topic:  True Cross-Platform Applications with React

React and React Native have come a long way in making sharing code possible between webapps and mobile apps.  We went from needing three different developers to write a feature, to one developer writing a feature twice in the same language.  This was a great step forward, but what if it possible to make that a single developer writing a feature only once?  This talk will explore building true cross-platform applications using dependency injection and a small set of primitives with shared interfaces across different platforms. 

This is the quarterly Triangle Modern Web event! Please RSVP here.

events.name: Full Stack Dev w JavaScript, NoSQL, Utility First CSS ++. Co-host: Modern Web +
events.description:
It's the first GDG event of the new year! Partnered with 8+ meetups in the area, we are looking forward to bringing together the JavaScript community in the new year.

PLEASE RSVP AT TRIANGLE MODERN WEB SO WE HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT FOR FOOD AND CHAIRS https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/246419998/

Special thanks to Tanium for sponsoring food and drinks at this event! We love the Tanium team!

Co-Hosts: Modern Web, TriangleJS, Angular RTP, Triangle React, Code Craftsmanship Saturdays, Triangle Ember, and more!

Please join us for our first event!

Featured Talks:

Full Stack Development with JavaScript and NoSQL
Speaker: Aaron Benton, Solutions Architect, Couchbase
Description: In a typical scenario, full stack applications are very modular, where every component can be changed independently from the rest of the application. The backend and frontend technologies can be totally different. However, what if they did not have to be?

In this session, we’re going to explore full stack development where each component is based on JavaScript and why keeping the technologies the same is a good thing. Then we’re going to see where NoSQL fits in and why it works so seamless with JavaScript.

Utility First CSS - A Lightweight, Scalable Solution
Speaker: Jake Dohm, Web Developer

Description:
In this session we'll talk about what Utility (or functional) CSS is, its common benefits and pitfalls, and address some common questions and concerns, like:
- What about "separation of concerns"?
- How is Utility CSS any different from inline styles?
- Does the Utility First mindset hold up at a larger scale?
- Does it have a positive or adverse effect on performance?

More info coming soon!

Want to speak at one of our events? Email [masked] anytime!

PLEASE RSVP AT TRIANGLE MODERN WEB SO WE HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT FOR FOOD AND CHAIRS https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/246419998/

events.name: Modern Web April: GraphQL, Open Source Web Components, Node + Express
events.description:
The 2nd quarterly Modern Web event has officially been announced and GDG Triangle is co-hosting!

There will be tons of great co-hosts per usual: Triangle React, Code Craftsmanship Saturdays, Triangle Javascript, RTP Angular, Triangle Ember, Triangle Ruby and more!

Don’t forget to share and invite others!

*PLEASE RSVP AT TRIANGLE MODERN WEB SO WE HAVE AN ACCURATE HEADCOUNT FOR FOOD AND CHAIRS
https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/246458813/

Don't miss out on some great talks!

Featured:

Title: Rethinking Data with GraphQL
Speaker: Ryan Chenkie, Google Developer Expert, Angularcasts, and Front End Masters

Description:
GraphQL has a simple goal: allow the client to ask for exactly the data it needs. The problem is that this requires a big shift in thinking about how data interactions should look. Once you’re able to “think in GraphQL”, however, you won’t want to go back. I’ll show you how to do just that.

Title: Open Source Web Components
Speaker: Tom Dalbo, Senior Software Engineer on Red Hat Customer Platform

Description:
Web Components aren’t scary anymore! We’re building applications with RHElements - extensible, standards-based, accessible, and open source. This talk will walk through how you can build your applications with web components without having to sacrifice browser compatibility, accessibility, SEO, or conforming to a single front-end framework across your organization. More info coming soon.

Title: NativeScript “Zero to Hero”
Speaker: Mark Halpin, Software Developer & NativeScript Expert

Do you have a great idea for a mobile application, but don’t know Java or Swift? Do you want to develop an application as quickly as possible using the web skills you already have?

If you haven’t heard of NativeScript, then you are in for a treat. NativeScript is framework that allows you to build cross platform mobile apps using common web technologies like HTML, CSS, JavaScript and XML that look, feel and perform like native applications. Not only can you use plain JavaScript, but you can also leverage the frameworks you already know to help build those native applications and integrate functionality such as location services, the camera, and push notifications. In this session, you will learn the basics of NativeScript and how to get started with Vue, as well as the tools you will need to start building and packaging native applications.

events.name: Google I/O Extended at the American Underground
events.description:
Google, the GDG and Momentum Learning will co-host a Google I/O Extended in Durham's American Underground on May 8, 2018. The event will feature Google coders and representatives from the local dev community.

Please register only if you're sure to come, but we look forward to seeing you there!

Go to https://www.universe.com/events/google-i-o-extended-day-session-durham-tickets-ZR325J for tickets!

events.name: Reactive Programming & Map Integrations - WTM Event, Durham
events.description:
We are partnering with Triangle Javascript and Women Techmakers for our first Triangle WTM event in Durham on June 5th!

Viget will be sponsoring the space + beer, soda, & pizza :)

Featured Speakers:

Annie Kiley, Developer at Viget
"Mapping a Night Out - Simple Map Integrations for the Web"

While working on an app to help a friend plan a group night out, we wanted to do a few simple things with a map. In this talk, I'll walk through three of the approaches we considered with the goal of showing some fun ways you can integrate an interactive map into your web app.

Tracy Lee, This Dot Co-founder, GDE, RxJs Core Team
“Reactive Programming Demystified”

There will always be a new JavaScript framework to learn. Technology will continue to evolve and change, and developers will continue to rewrite applications. Wouldn't it be amazing if we could just copy paste 90% of our code from framework to framework?

Well, you can. Reactive programming enables just this AND the ability to future proof your code.

Come out and listen to some great talks!
events.how_to_find_us: PARKING: Anywhere downtown Durham - free after 6pm. Take elevator to the 4th floor.

events.name: Machine Learning w/ BrainJS, Cambridge Ana-cynical, PWA and Web Components
events.description:
We are co-hosting another Modern Web event!

Along with Triangle Ember, Triangle Javascript, Angular RTP, Triangle Node, Code Craftsmanship, Triangle React, Triangle Ruby, and Triangle Elixir.

Pendo is sponsoring food + venue

There will be a special talk called "Getting Kids Involved as Programmers/Developers in Building Today's Digital World"
from Timothy Amadi. He is 10 year old developer and founder of his own company, Bug Zero Codes!

MAKE SURE YOU RSVP AT TRIANGLE MODERN WEB FOR ACCURATE HEADCOUNT
https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/250077088/

Featured Talks:

Speaker: Jeff Mahoney, Software Developer, IBM Watson Health

“Get Your AI On: Machine Learning with JavaScript using BrainJS”

Description:
Classes and toolkits for machine learning are everywhere... if you like coding in Python or R. But what about the intrepid developers out there who want to play with machine learning using JavaScript? Is there a solution for them?

The answer is yes. In this presentation, we will walk through training a neural network using BrainJS, a wonderful library that allows us to do this in a language most (all?) front-end and web developers are familiar with. Come and watch the birth of SkyNet with JS!

Speaker: Marcus Hellburg, lead developer advocate at Vaadin, helping developers learn about modern web technologies, background in embedded systems but has worked on everything web related for the past 15+ years.

“Hands-on with PWA and Web Components”

Description:
The web is turning into an application platform. Web Components give us a way of defining reusable UI components. Progressive Web Applications improve performance in poor network conditions. You can install them on your phone and they can send you notifications of important events.

In this presentation, we'll learn the basics of Web Components and Progressive Web Applications by building a small application from scratch. After the presentation, you will have the skills needed to get started working on your own PWA.

Speaker: Peter Elbaum, Software Engineer at Smashing Boxes

“Cambridge Ana-cynical: Understanding the Facebook information scandal and its APIs”

Description:
In the spring of this year, it became public knowledge that as many as 87 million Facebook users had their data mined by an app developed by the political data firm Cambridge Analytica. These events prompted many questions including inquiries about whether or not the data access was legal. From a software development perspective, one wonders how exactly the data mining was achieved. With that in mind, this talk will dive into the breach and the capabilities of Facebook's public APIs. We will survey what people developing on Facebook's platform are able to accomplish and the data that's immediately available to them. We'll also demo of some of the common utilities that are possible using the Facebook Javascript SDK.

Speaker: Jay Phelps, Reactive programming nut and compiler enthusiast. He is the Chief Software Architect at This Dot, previously a Senior Software Engineer at Netflix. Lover of all things open source, RxJS core team member and author of core-decorators, git-blame-someone-else, and co-author of redux-observable.

“Help me WebAssembly, you're my only hope!”

Description:
WebAssembly (aka wasm) is a new, standardized compilation target for the web, shipping in all modern browsers. But since it's so low level it can be difficult to see how it will revolutionize the next generation of web apps–and definitely not just games and C++! In this talk, Jay will reveal what it is, how you can use it today, and the incredible opportunities it will unlock in the years to come on both the Web and on Desktop.

https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/250077088/

events.name: UX Research Methods, Rise of the Data Driven Business + More
events.description:
Join us in Durham for some amazing talks and discussions!

Melissa Eggleston, Director of User Experience, Teamworks

Talk Title: UX Research Methods: No Ph.D. Needed

Talk Description: What value does UX research bring to designers and developers? What are commonly used UX research methods? How do you know which one to use when? Who can conduct these different types of research? We'll discuss various research methodologies and give specific examples of how they are used by organizations of all sizes to improve software, websites, and other systems.

Rachael Classi, Director of Growth, Teamworks. MBA, Duke University, The Fuqua School of Business. Concentrations in Finance and Entrepreneurship.

Talk Title: The rise of the data driven business.

Talk Description: Companies talk about the increasing importance of data in driving business decisions but data means different things to different functions. This conversation will focus on the rise of and differences between data in leadership, marketing, sales, customer success, product, and engineering. We will briefly discuss how to access gain fluency in function-specific data tools and best practices for interpreting data.

Ellen Gowdy, Director of Recruitment, Teamworks, Founder and Owner of Curious,

Talk Title: Positioning yourself for the job you want

Talk Description: Finding and landing the right job for you can be a challenge even in a hot job market. Making a shift to a new career or industry can be even more difficult. With years of experience helping companies put the right people in the right seats, Ellen Gowdy will help you define tools and strategies to land that perfect job. This talk will cover networking strategies, tips for cold outreach, how to present yourself online and advice for making a career or industry shift.

events.name: Modern Web October - Get Spooky with Elixir and D3
events.description:
Join us for another co-hosted event with Modern Web!

RSVP at https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/254480300/

We are partnering with many wonderful JavaScript meetups: Triangle Modern Web, TriangleJS, GDG Triangle, Code Craftsmanship Saturdays, Triangle Ember, and Triangle Node.

This event is sponsored by Pendo and All Things Open (Thx Pendo for the pizza and space!).

Location: Pendo in downtown Raleigh - 4th floor of the Wells Fargo Building

Featured Talks:

Speaker - David Bernheisel - Software Engineer at Viget Labs

Why is Elixir So Enjoyable?

Elixir is an up-and-coming language that many developers have heard about being really enjoyable. It's superfast with microsecond web response times, can be embedded into hardware, and respected developers have started migrating to use Elixir. David is going to break down why and what makes it so enjoyable.

Speaker - Jamie Bort -

D3

With the JavaScript library D3.js we can now easily do that right in the browser.

This is done by binding arbitrary data to the Document Object Model, and then applying data-driven transformations to the document.

Jamie will first briefly demonstrate how to set up the library. He will then demonstrating different ways to display a few data set using D3.js.

Speaker - Brandon Mathis - Freelance Software Developer and co-founder of GroundLift He is obsessed with helping technology companies and individuals in Triangle realize their full potential!

Scaling Your User Interface With A Design System

We spend so much time thinking about how our applications scale, do we give the same amount of thought towards how our user interfaces scale? Technology products can span across a multitude of platforms from web to native to desktop, mobile, and tablet. Companies can change and evolve. Crunch time doesn't allow us the care and forethought needed to build a consistent impactful user interface. Let me share with you how a Design System, consisting of a library of repeatable components and standards guiding the use of those components, can help your team scale your application across a variety of platforms.

RSVP at https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/254480300/

events.name: Modern Web January - Special Event with John Papa and others! Celebrate 2019!
events.description:
Happy New Year!

Who's ready for some great food, company, and presentations? Come out and join us to discuss everything JS.

** This is a Modern Web event - RSVP at https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/257842264/ **

We are partnering with some awesome JavaScript meetups: Triangle Modern Web, Triangle Serverless, Triangle JS, Angular RTP, Code Craftsmanship Saturdays, and Triangle Node.

Thanks to our sponsors: ATO (All Things Open) and Allstacks.

Location: HQ Capital Club in downtown Raleigh - 12th floor

Featured Talks:

Speaker - John Papa - Developer Advocate at Microsoft

Developing with JavaScript in 2019

Whether you choose Angular, React or Vue, you may benefit from understanding how building an app in each of them feels. Can we build the same things? Can we debug them the same way? Can we deploy them with docker to the cloud? Join me and let's explore what it means to be a JavaScript developer in 2019.

Speaker - Alan Ball

Turn F# into Javascript with Fable

In this talk I'll be answering what F# is, when you might want to consider using it, and how it can be used with Fable (F# Babel) and React components to build functional type-safe websites.

Speaker - Jake Dohm - Web Developer

Cleaning Up Your Function Parameters

Function parameters are one of the fundamentals of writing JS, but just because they’re fundamental doesn’t mean you can’t improve how you use them. In this talk, we’ll quickly refactor a function to clean up it’s parameters, making it easier to use and read!

Speaker - Jarrod Overson - Director at Shape Security

** This is a Modern Web event - RSVP at https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/257842264/ **

events.name: Triangle DevFest
events.description:
Triangle DevFest is here and we have some amazing speakers to talk to you about headless chrome, containers, kubernetes and GAE!

https://triangledevfest.firebaseapp.com

Food, drinks, swag and fun will be provided.

Speaker Lineup:

Jarrod Overson, Director, Shape Security
Topic: Automating Chrome with Puppeteer

Description:
You know that automation is important in every aspect of development, but how many times have you automated web page interaction? Automating browsers used to be a cumbersome process prone to breaking but now, with Puppeteer, setting up automated browser scripts is easy and fun. In this talk Jarrod will go over Puppeteer, the Chrome DevTools Protocol, and how to get started taking control of your browser.

Shika Srivastava, Senior Technical Staff Member (STSM) and a Master Inventor at IBM
Topic: Containerized Applications to Secure and Scaling with Kubernetes

What does it really take to make sure your application is production ready?
How can you make sure your containerized application is production ready and how can you make sure of right scale, availability and security set up for your containerized application in hosting environment. I will cover all aspects from start to finish on how to deliver production-ready code.

Chris DeMars
Front-End Developer, Tuft & Needle
Topic: I Can't See: Low Vision A11y & Users

When you think of low vision, what comes to mind? A user that is near sighted? How about far sighted? Maybe partially blind? These are all qualifying cases of poor vision, but low vision is more complicated than the prescription of glasses or contacts.

According to the World Health Organization, they categorize low vision based on specific levels of visual acuity and field of vision (http://W3.org , 2016). With that in mind, we as developers can look at different categories of low vision including color vision, visual acuity, contrast sensitivity, etc and make an effort to bake in things like zoom, non-conflicting colors, and re-wrapping of columns in to our code.

My talk will cover what vision accessibility is, different categories of low vision, what the needs of the users are, and what we as developers can do to achieve a great user experience for low vision users.

Diana Rodriguez, Chief DevOps Architect at Voicethread
Topic: Containers 101: Docker and Kubernetes Simplified

Lightening Speakers:

Kelly Carijen
Topic: Focus: One way to get it and keep it

James Luterek
Topic: Trends in commerce

BugZeroCodes
Timothy, Daniel, and Eugene
Topic: The role of kids in TECH, the fastest growing professional community in the world.

events.name: GDG Triangle / Women Techmakers Quarterly Meetup
events.description:
Please join us for the quarterly GDG Triangle partnered with Women Techmakers meetup.

Speaker Lineup:
Leila Alderman
Topic: Save the world from your couch with open-source mapping

Humanitarian crises happen all too often and frequently happen in places far from our homes. One way we can help is to provide up-to-date map information for the affected regions. This may sound complicated, but it’s actually so easy that anyone with a laptop can do it. Really, anyone!

While map information for the U.S. is pretty great, the map information for people escaping a violent militia near Lake Chad is pretty poor because nobody has needed to or been paid to map that area. As humanitarian relief efforts put boots on the ground, they need maps, but they often lack even just the basics of which roads go where.

By looking at an up-to-date satellite image, you can trace roads or draw a box around the hospitals and schools in a town with a few clicks of your mouse. Adding this data to an open-source map can save lives even within an hour of the update.

In short, if you can trace lines with your mouse, you can save lives!

Joy Kaufman
Topic: Imposter syndrome vs cognitive dissonance for women
events.how_to_find_us: Parking for this event is located at the dirt parking lot directly next to Smashing Boxes. You will enter through the back of the building via the parking lot as the front door on the street will be locked.

events.name: Triangle Modern Web+Devs@RTP- Testing, Code Reviews, Hugo, Accessibility + more!
events.description:
This is a special Triangle Modern Web + Devs@RTP event!

We are co-hosting with Angular RTP, Triangle Node, TriangleJS, Code Craftsmanship Saturday, Triangle Elixir, Triangle React, All Things Open, Downtown Techies, & Triangle .NET User Group!

RSVP here: https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/259551933/

Special thanks to Nutanix, Vaco, All Things Open, and This Dot Labs for sponsoring the event.

This will be held from 6:30PM - 9:30PM on April 25, 2019 at Nutanix 701 W Main St Suite 700 · Durham, NC

We have some amazing talks planned for you!

Our lineup of speakers:

Speaker - Todd Jordan
"Keep Your Tests Sweet: Developing a test strategy that keeps you productive as you grow"

Description - We'll look back at some classic writings on software and manufacturing to provide some wisdom today in developing an automated test suite for you web app
that will keep you productive as your project expands.

Speaker - Ben McCormick
"A Second Set Of Eyes: Getting The Most From Code Reviews"

Description - Effective code reviews can improve code quality, spread knowledge around the team, create avenues for mentorship and clarify gaps in understanding. But many teams go without them or fail to reap all of the benefits that they might bring. This talk will discuss practical steps for implementing better code reviews that benefit your whole team.

Lightning Talks:

Speaker - Mark Haplin
"Working with Hugo, the Static Site Generator"

Speaker - Tracy Lee
"Diversity and Inclusion in Tech"
Description - Everyone is talking about diversity and inclusion these days. But why does it really matter? And if you’ve had a hard time finding women to hire, how do you solve that problem? What are some ways companies have done D&I right, and how can you learn from them?

Speaker - Daniel Amadi
"How to grow the tech community in your home"

Speaker - Eugene Amadi
"When to grow the tech community in your home"

Speaker - Timothy Amadi
"Why you need to grow the tech community in your home"

Speaker - Rob Ocel
"A Geometric Analogy For Software Development"
Description - Want a simple way to understand and explain the relationship between requirements and implementations? Requirement constraints vs assumptions? Implementations and tests? I'll share a visualization that I've used as a mentor to help newer developers understand these concepts!

Speaker - Maria Lamardo
"Accessibility"

Don't forget to RSVP here: https://www.meetup.com/trianglemodernweb/events/259551933/

See you in a few weeks!

Parking Instructions:

The West Pettigrew Parking Deck
704 W. Pettigrew Street, Durham, NC 27701 - https://goo.gl/maps/A7yKuytr7fD2

You can bring the parking ticket from this parking lot to the office for validation - Please use the following walking instructions to the a: Walk North on South Gregson Street to Main Street. Make a right on Main Street and cross over Duke Street using the crosswalk at the traffic light. The Chesterfield main entrance is located on Main Street.

There is limited free parking behind the building (on the intersection of S Duke St and W Peabody St https://goo.gl/maps/HmmH2q6ePbJ2). If you park here, make sure it is only behind OUR building.

There is also street parking.
